criteria: Understanding of When to Seek Help
descriptions: The student cannot identify any safe people to turn to when feeling unsafe or threatened.
The student can identify one safe person but struggles to articulate why they are safe or appropriate.
The student can identify 2 safe people but may not fully explain their roles or why they are safe.
The student can identify 3 safe people and briefly explains their roles and suitability in unsafe situations.
The student accurately identifies multiple safe people (e.g., school counselor, trusted teacher, family member) and clearly explains their roles and suitability in providing support and safety.

The student comprehensively identifies a wide range of safe people, providing detailed explanations of their roles, suitability, and the specific ways they can offer support in various unsafe or threatening situations. The student demonstrates a nuanced understanding of trust and safety.
The student cannot identify any safe places to go to when feeling unsafe or threatened.
The student identifies one place that is not necessarily safe or appropriate.
The student can identify one safe place but struggles to articulate why it is safe or appropriate.
The student identifies 2 safe places and adequately explains why they are safe and accessible.

The student accurately identifies multiple safe places (e.g., school, police department, fire department, community center) and clearly explains their accessibility, safety features, and the types of support available.

The student comprehensively identifies a variety of safe places, providing detailed explanations of their features, accessibility at different times, and the specific resources or support available. The student demonstrates a strong understanding of environmental safety.
The student does not demonstrate an understanding of when it is necessary to seek help from safe people or go to safe places.
The student vaguely recognizes the need for help in extreme situations only.
The student identifies a few situations where seeking help would be appropriate, but lacks clarity on when to act.
The student demonstrates a general understanding of when to seek help in unsafe or threatening situations, but may hesitate in certain scenarios.
The student clearly articulates various scenarios where seeking help from safe people or going to safe places is necessary, demonstrating a proactive approach to personal safety.

The student demonstrates a nuanced and comprehensive understanding of when to seek help, considering various factors and potential barriers. The student advocates for seeking help early and often to prevent escalation.
